title: Royal Netherlands Navy – NATO role classification
intro: In NATO recognition, classify ships by role and capability.
Use simple English: 'This is a … It is used for …'.

bullets: Operates underwater for stealth.
Used for intelligence and sea denial.
Carries torpedoes and sensors.
Submarine.why_not: Not a surface ship because it operates mainly underwater.

bullets: Multi-role warship for escort and task groups.
Often used for air defence and anti-submarine warfare.
Has advanced sensors and weapons.
Frigate.why_not: Not a patrol vessel because it has heavier combat capability.

bullets: Used for maritime security and patrol tasks.
Usually lighter weapons than major warships.
Long endurance for presence at sea.
Patrol Vessel.why_not: Not a frigate because it has fewer sensors and lighter weapons.

bullets: Used to transport troops and vehicles.
Can support landings with landing craft and helicopters.
Acts as a command and support platform.
Amphibious Ship.why_not: Not a frigate because its main role is transport and landing support.

bullets: Used to detect and neutralize sea mines.
Specialized sonar and mine disposal systems.
Often supports safe routes for other ships.
Mine Countermeasures Vessel.why_not: Not a patrol vessel because its primary mission is mine warfare.

bullets: Provides fuel, food, ammunition, or repairs at sea.
Keeps task groups operational for longer.
Usually not designed for front-line combat.
Support Vessel.why_not: Not a frigate because its main role is logistics, not combat.

bullets: Special-purpose vessels that do not fit the main roles.
Classify by best match; if unsure, use Other.
Teacher can discuss the closest NATO role.
Other.why_not: Used when the primary role is unclear or unique.
